desc.size: Tree, 9 - 11 m tall. Crown compact, oval.

part.partText: greenish brown, lustrous, smooth. Young growth sticky.
yellow to glossy brown, small, egg-shaped, pointed.

alternate, with 6.5 mm - 1.25 cm long, glandular leafstalks; lustrous dark green above, paler beneath, midrib yellow, 4 - 12.5 cm long, 2 - 5 cm wide, elliptical to egg-shaped to elliptical-lanceolate, base rounded or slightly heart-shaped, tip short-pointed, margins finely toothed, teeth glandular, thick, smooth, aromatic when bruised.

either male or female, borne on separate trees (dioecious); in hairy, cylindrical catkins on short, leafy stalks; female catkins 3 - 6 cm long, ovary hairless; male catkins 3 - 5 cm long, stamens 5 to 12, scales yellow, anthers yellow; insect- and wind-pollinated.
a capsule; in elongated clusters; short-stalked, greenish to light brown, to 10 mm long, flask-shaped; seeds with long, white, silky hairs attached; dispersed by wind and water.

similarSpecies.comments: Salix pentandra is distinguished from most other willows in the Chicago Region by having finely toothed leaves that are green and hairless on both sides. Leaf margins are flat, not revolute (down-curved). Salix eriocephala has lanceolate leaves; S. lucida has shiny leaves that are typically less wide; S. nigra has narrowly lanceolate leaves.

speciesPage.habitatEcology: Along rivers, streams, lakes, and other wet sites, probably as an escape from cultivation.

notes.comments: A very attractive species introduced from Europe.

etymology.comments: Salix is the Latin word for willow. Pentandra means “with five stamens.”
